for_sales.sales_text:
Florence emerged after a two year complete refit inside and out as "Daisy". Like a Phoenix from the flames, she is now totally waterproofed, looks beautiful and sails like a dream. Any serious purchaser needs to visit me and "Daisy", see all the work, invoices and information to appreciate her full worth.

Refit work

All deck fittings removed and old polyester sheathing removed, allowed to dry out, then recovered in modern glass fibre and slow cure epoxy. Cabin sides stripped, portholes removed, deck recoated with anti-slip paint, all fixtures and fittings including tabernacle and portholes rebedded on sealant and all refixed with silicone bronze and galvanised fixings as appropriate.

The hull was stripped back to gel-coat, no osmosis was found, sanded and five coats of two pack epoxy zinc phoshate primer applied followed by top coat of two pack finish and finally antifouling.

A new stainless steel propshaft was made, new cutlass bearing installed and gland packing renewed. A mast repair was carried out by a local boatbuilding company and a classic marine goose neck fitted.

Sails were inspected and repaired by Jessails who also made a new mainsail cover, and summer and winter cockpit and hatch covers.

Cabin roofs were finished with insulated panels between the mahogany beams which prevents condensation.

boat.full_description:
First launched as Impudence 1984 - 1988, she was renamed Florence 1988 - 1991. Taking the name Veejur from 1992 - 2000 she reverted to Florence in 2001. In 2008 she was purchased by Tim Stephenson and transported to Kirkcudbright from Isle of Oronsay but Tim did not have time to complete all the work. In 2010 she was sold to Derek and Valerie Smith with a  leaking deck, the marine ply and mahogany begining to deteriorate.

With the gift of a big free trailer and the use of a large barn with electricity, Florence entered the barn in 2011 to emerge two years later as Daisy, with new epoxy deck and a complete refit.
boat.name: Daisy
boat.short_description: With a hull purchased from North Cornwall Marine, 1984, by Ted Smith who fitted her out, Impudence was sailing in 1986. After several name changes, she emerged from a major refit, 2011 - 2013 as Daisy.
